descript.abstract:
This watershed feature class was derived from USGS NED data @ 1:24,000 scale. These watersheds or subwatersheds contribute to naturally flowing waters that traverse the City of Asheville corporate limits or ETJ. These watershed boundaries are specifically geared for use in public education and outreach and general City of Asheville staff knowledge. As the watersheds were processed from DEMs, the boundaries themselves are not contour-derived and should be used cautiously if precision is required.
These watersheds were derived by processing USGS NED DEMs using the hydrologic geoprocessing tools found in ArcInfo 9.1 and Spatial Analyst. Please refer to the processing steps listed further in the metadata or contact the metadata author for further details on processing steps and methods.
descript.purpose: For use in City Planning related to water quality, engineering, and land use management.

idinfo.useconst: Not intended for use in calculating drainage areas in any way, shape, or form. In particular, this dataset should not be used for calculating drainage areas for h&h modeling, engineering structures, etc..
idinfo.datacred: Nick Harvey - City of Asheville Engineering Department.
idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 3; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.3.1.1850

attracc.attraccr: Watershed names were obtained from their associated arterial tributary names if available on USGS 7.5' Quadrangles.

dataqual.logic: Topology is clean per cluster tolerance. All attribution is clean and consistent.
dataqual.complete: This feature class contains all drainage areas that spatially overlap (intersect) the City of Asheville and associated ETJ. However, drainage areas that extend outside of the ETJ are not included in their entirety. For example, subwatersheds of the Swannanoa are included, but not the larger contributing drainage area which extends to the limits of Buncombe County, etc...

procstep.procdesc: 10m NED DEMs were reprojected and mosaiced for our region in the NCSP Coordinate System (Feet-NAD83) into a single DEM. This DEM was filled for sinks (internal drainage). Flow Direction and Flow Accumulation were calculated for this resulting "depressionless" DEM. The Hydro Tools sample extension Watershed Tool (ArcInfo 9.1; Spatial Analyst) was then used to create subwatersheds with drainage of 1000 cells each. These raster watersheds were then vectorized and aggregated according to arterial tributaries.

altsys.altenc: Explicit elevation coordinate included with horizontal coordinates

attr.attrdef: Name of watershed per arterial tributary

metainfo.metstdn: FGDC Content Standards for Digital Geospatial Metadata
